useStmt.citReq:
Publications and research reports based on the IPUMS-PMA database must cite it appropriately. The citation should include the following:
Elizabeth Heger Boyle, Devon Kristiansen, and Matthew Sobek. IPUMS-PMA: Version 1.0 [dataset] Minneapolis, MN: IPUMS, 2018. https://doi.org/10.18128/D081.V1.0
The licensing agreement for use of IPUMS-PMA data requires that users supply us with the title and full citation for any publications, research reports, or educational materials making use of the data or documentation. Please add your citation to the IPUMS bibliography at http://bibliography.ipums.org/.
useStmt.conditions:
Users of IPUMS-PMA data must agree to abide by the conditions of use. A user's license is valid for one year and may be renewed. Users must agree to the following conditions:
(1) No fees may be charged for use or distribution of the data.
(2) Cite IPUMS appropriately. For information on proper citation, refer to the citation requirement section of this DDI document.
(3) Tell us about any work you do using the IPUMS. Publications, research reports, or presentations making use of IPUMS-PMA should be added to our Bibliography. Continued funding for the IPUMS depends on our ability to show our sponsor agencies that researchers are using the data for productive purposes.
(4) The IPUMS cannot be used for genealogical research
(5) It is difficult to use the IPUMS to study small geographic areas. In the IPUMS census samples for years 1940-present, no places having a population of fewer than 100,000 persons can be identified.
(6) Use it for GOOD -- never for EVIL.
(7) Please notify ipums@umn.edu regarding errors in the data or documentation.
useStmt.disclaimer: The user of the data acknowledges that the original collector of the data, the authorized distributor of the data, and the relevant funding agency bear no responsibility for use of the data or for interpretations or inferences based upon such uses.

stdyDscr.notes: User-provided description: longitudinal tech (wide) - all cases

fileTxt.filePlac: IPUMS, 50 Willey Hall, 225 - 19th Avenue South, Minneapolis, MN 55455

var.name: SAMPLE_1
var.txt: SAMPLE is an IPUMS-generated variable that identifies the PMA sample from which the record is drawn. In some countries and years, PMA conducts more than one round of the survey. The data from each round are separately identified. In some cases, data from the same country and same round might have been split into more than one file according to geographic region.

Nigeria (Kano and Lagos) 2019 Client Exit Interview

var.name: SAMPLE_2
var.txt: SAMPLE is an IPUMS-generated variable that identifies the PMA sample from which the record is drawn. In some countries and years, PMA conducts more than one round of the survey. The data from each round are separately identified. In some cases, data from the same country and same round might have been split into more than one file according to geographic region.

catgry.labl: Congo, Democratic Republic (Kinshasa and Kongo Central) 2019 Baseline
Congo, Democratic Republic (Kinshasa and Kongo Central) 2020 Client Exit Interview

var.name: COUNTRY
var.txt: COUNTRY reports the country where the survey was fielded.

var.name: YEAR_1
var.txt: YEAR reports the year when the survey was fielded. Some interviews may have occurred early in the following year. YEAR does not reflect individual interview years.

var.name: YEAR_2
var.txt: YEAR reports the year when the survey was fielded. Some interviews may have occurred early in the following year. YEAR does not reflect individual interview years.

var.name: HHID_1
var.txt:
HHID is an IPUMS-constructed variable that uniquely identifies households. HHID is a concatenation of enumeration area ID number (EAID), a count variable starting from one corresponding to each value of HHIDORIG, year (YEAR), and round (ROUND).
For cases where HHIDORIG is missing, HHID is a concatenation of enumeration area ID (EAID), household structure number (STRUCTURNO), household number within structure (HHNUM), year (YEAR), and round (ROUND).
HHID does not allow users to link records of households that have been interviewed in more than one round of survey of PMA.
A different construction is used for cases in which STRUCTURNO and/or HHNUM are missing, or if EAID is not available. See the Comparability tab for more details.
var.codInstr: This is a 27-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: HHID_2
var.txt:
HHID is an IPUMS-constructed variable that uniquely identifies households. HHID is a concatenation of enumeration area ID number (EAID), a count variable starting from one corresponding to each value of HHIDORIG, year (YEAR), and round (ROUND).
For cases where HHIDORIG is missing, HHID is a concatenation of enumeration area ID (EAID), household structure number (STRUCTURNO), household number within structure (HHNUM), year (YEAR), and round (ROUND).
HHID does not allow users to link records of households that have been interviewed in more than one round of survey of PMA.
A different construction is used for cases in which STRUCTURNO and/or HHNUM are missing, or if EAID is not available. See the Comparability tab for more details.
var.codInstr: This is a 27-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: RESPONDENT_1
var.txt: RESPONDENT indicates whether the person was the respondent to the household questionnaire. The household respondent reported information about the assets, access to water, and other information about the household, including the roster of household members.

var.name: RESPONDENT_2
var.txt: RESPONDENT indicates whether the person was the respondent to the household questionnaire. The household respondent reported information about the assets, access to water, and other information about the household, including the roster of household members.

var.name: ELIGIBLE_1
var.txt: ELIGIBLE identifies women aged 15 to 49 who were eligible to answer the female questionnaire. It is possible to have multiple eligible women in the same household, or no eligible women in the household.

var.name: ELIGIBLE_2
var.txt: ELIGIBLE identifies women aged 15 to 49 who were eligible to answer the female questionnaire. It is possible to have multiple eligible women in the same household, or no eligible women in the household.

var.name: LINENO_1
var.txt: LINENO is an IPUMS-constructed technical variable that numbers all persons within each household according to their order in the original data. The variable LINEORIG reports the original line number of a household member. The main difference between LINEORIG and LINENO is that values in LINENO are without duplicates and have been corrected when numbers in LINEORIG were skipped.

var.name: LINENO_2
var.txt: LINENO is an IPUMS-constructed technical variable that numbers all persons within each household according to their order in the original data. The variable LINEORIG reports the original line number of a household member. The main difference between LINEORIG and LINENO is that values in LINENO are without duplicates and have been corrected when numbers in LINEORIG were skipped.

var.name: STRUCTURNO_1
var.txt:
STRUCTURNO is the number assigned by PMA2020 to the physical structure in which the household lives. The variable HHNUM reports the number of the dwelling within the structure in which the interviewed household lives.
This variable may include non-integer values in select samples. These values were not edited by IPUMS and are from the original data.
var.codInstr:
This is a numeric variable that represents structure where the household lives, except for the following code:
999998 = No response or missing

var.name: STRUCTURNO_2
var.txt:
STRUCTURNO is the number assigned by PMA2020 to the physical structure in which the household lives. The variable HHNUM reports the number of the dwelling within the structure in which the interviewed household lives.
This variable may include non-integer values in select samples. These values were not edited by IPUMS and are from the original data.
var.codInstr:
This is a numeric variable that represents structure where the household lives, except for the following code:
999998 = No response or missing

var.name: HHNUM_1
var.txt: HHNUM is the number assigned to the household's dwelling within a given structure (STRUCTURNO). There can be multiple dwellings within one structure, such as individual apartments (dwellings) in an apartment building (a structure). Households are defined as a group of people who live and eat together in the same dwelling.
var.codInstr: This is a 5-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: HHNUM_2
var.txt: HHNUM is the number assigned to the household's dwelling within a given structure (STRUCTURNO). There can be multiple dwellings within one structure, such as individual apartments (dwellings) in an apartment building (a structure). Households are defined as a group of people who live and eat together in the same dwelling.
var.codInstr: This is a 5-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: EAID_1
var.txt:
EAID reports the geographic enumeration area where the respondent was located. The EAID is the primary sampling unit for IPUMS PMA. Due to privacy concerns, the borders of these enumeration areas are not publicly available and the enumeration area is specified via an assigned number rather than a recognized name for a locale.
Enumeration areas do not cover all areas within each survey country. After 5 survey rounds using the same enumeration areas, PMA identifies new enumeration areas. Due to this sampling design, some households, eligible women respondents, or service delivery points might be selected to be interviewed in more than one survey within a 5 year period. The variables PREVINTERVIEWHQ, PREVINTERVIEWFQ, and PREVINTERVIEWSQ identifies household, female, and service delivery point respondents, respectively, who have been interviewed for PMA in a previous round. It is not possible, however, to link survey records for the same person between rounds.
var.codInstr: This is a numeric variable that represents a primary sampling unit identifier.

var.name: EAID_2
var.txt:
EAID reports the geographic enumeration area where the respondent was located. The EAID is the primary sampling unit for IPUMS PMA. Due to privacy concerns, the borders of these enumeration areas are not publicly available and the enumeration area is specified via an assigned number rather than a recognized name for a locale.
Enumeration areas do not cover all areas within each survey country. After 5 survey rounds using the same enumeration areas, PMA identifies new enumeration areas. Due to this sampling design, some households, eligible women respondents, or service delivery points might be selected to be interviewed in more than one survey within a 5 year period. The variables PREVINTERVIEWHQ, PREVINTERVIEWFQ, and PREVINTERVIEWSQ identifies household, female, and service delivery point respondents, respectively, who have been interviewed for PMA in a previous round. It is not possible, however, to link survey records for the same person between rounds.
var.codInstr: This is a numeric variable that represents a primary sampling unit identifier.

var.name: ENUMID_1
var.txt: ENUMID is a randomly-generated number that identifies the enumerator who administered the survey.
var.codInstr:
This variable represents a random identifier assigned to an enumerator except for the following codes:
99996 = Not interviewed (household questionnaire) 99998 = No response or missing

var.name: ENUMID_2
var.txt: ENUMID is a randomly-generated number that identifies the enumerator who administered the survey.
var.codInstr:
This variable represents a random identifier assigned to an enumerator except for the following codes:
99996 = Not interviewed (household questionnaire) 99998 = No response or missing

var.name: CONSENTFQ_1
var.labl: Female respondent provided consent to be interviewed
var.txt: CONSENTFQ indicates whether or not the respondent to the female questionnaire completed the survey. The variable RESULTFQ provides more detail regarding why the interview was not conducted or completed.

var.name: CONSENTFQ_2
var.labl: Female respondent provided consent to be interviewed
var.txt: CONSENTFQ indicates whether or not the respondent to the female questionnaire completed the survey. The variable RESULTFQ provides more detail regarding why the interview was not conducted or completed.

var.name: AVAILABLEFQ_1
var.labl: Female respondent present and available to be interviewed
var.txt: AVAILABLEFQ indicates whether the woman who was eligible for the survey was present and available to be interviewed for the female questionnaire.

var.name: AVAILABLEFQ_2
var.labl: Female respondent present and available to be interviewed
var.txt: AVAILABLEFQ indicates whether the woman who was eligible for the survey was present and available to be interviewed for the female questionnaire.

var.name: FQACQUAINTED_1
var.labl: How well acquainted with the respondent
var.txt:
FQACQUAINTED indicates to what extent the interviewer was acquainted with the female questionnaire respondent. PMA2020 surveys were fielded by resident enumerators, meaning that the interviewers lived in or near the enumeration areas they surveyed.
The PMA2020 team used this variable to investigate the effect of the level of acquaintance with the resident enumerator on the answers given by female respondents, especially about sensitive issues such as use of contraception. See the methodological report for more details.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: FQACQUAINTED_2
var.labl: How well acquainted with the respondent
var.txt:
FQACQUAINTED indicates to what extent the interviewer was acquainted with the female questionnaire respondent. PMA2020 surveys were fielded by resident enumerators, meaning that the interviewers lived in or near the enumeration areas they surveyed.
The PMA2020 team used this variable to investigate the effect of the level of acquaintance with the resident enumerator on the answers given by female respondents, especially about sensitive issues such as use of contraception. See the methodological report for more details.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: VISITNUMFQ_1
var.txt:
VISITNUMFQ reports the number of times the enumerator visited the female respondent in the household in order to complete the female questionnaire interview. Up to three visits were made for each female questionnaire respondent.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: VISITNUMFQ_2
var.txt:
VISITNUMFQ reports the number of times the enumerator visited the female respondent in the household in order to complete the female questionnaire interview. Up to three visits were made for each female questionnaire respondent.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: RESULTFQ_1
var.txt: RESULTFQ indicates whether or not the respondent completed the female questionnaire and, if not, the reason why not.

var.name: RESULTFQ_2
var.txt: RESULTFQ indicates whether or not the respondent completed the female questionnaire and, if not, the reason why not.

var.name: CROSS_SECTION_1
var.labl: Observation is in the cross-sectional sample
var.txt: CROSS_SECTION indicates whether the person was included in the cross sectional sample for that year. If the person was not in the cross sectional sample, they were exclusively in the longitudinal sample. All persons in the cross sectional sample were also included in the longitudinal sample. See our sample notes on longitudinal data for more information.

var.name: CROSS_SECTION_2
var.labl: Observation is in the cross-sectional sample
var.txt: CROSS_SECTION indicates whether the person was included in the cross sectional sample for that year. If the person was not in the cross sectional sample, they were exclusively in the longitudinal sample. All persons in the cross sectional sample were also included in the longitudinal sample. See our sample notes on longitudinal data for more information.

var.name: RESULTLFQ_1
var.txt: RESULTLFQ indicates whether or not the respondent completed the longitudinal female questionnaire and, if not, the reason why not.

var.name: RESULTLFQ_2
var.txt: RESULTLFQ indicates whether or not the respondent completed the longitudinal female questionnaire and, if not, the reason why not.

var.name: INTFQMON_1
var.txt: INTFQMON reports the calendar month in which the interview for the female questionnaire was conducted. The year of the female interview can be found in the variable INTFQYEAR.

var.name: INTFQMON_2
var.txt: INTFQMON reports the calendar month in which the interview for the female questionnaire was conducted. The year of the female interview can be found in the variable INTFQYEAR.

var.name: INTFQYEAR_1
var.txt: INTFQYEAR reports the calendar year in which the interview for the female questionnaire was conducted. The month of the female interview can be found in the variable INTFQMON.

var.name: INTFQYEAR_2
var.txt: INTFQYEAR reports the calendar year in which the interview for the female questionnaire was conducted. The month of the female interview can be found in the variable INTFQMON.

var.name: FQINSTID
var.txt: FQINSTID is a constructed variable that uniquely identifies each respondent to the female questionnaire across all PMA samples. If a woman was interviewed in multiple rounds of PMA, FQINSTID cannot be used to link the same woman between samples because a new value for FQINSTID is generated for each "instance" of a woman's interview.
var.codInstr: This is a 50-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: CONSENTHQ_1
var.labl: Household respondent provided consent to be interviewed
var.txt: CONSENTHQ indicates whether or not the respondent for the household survey consented to be interviewed and completed the survey. The variable RESULTHQ provides more detail regarding why the interview was not conducted or completed.

var.name: CONSENTHQ_2
var.labl: Household respondent provided consent to be interviewed
var.txt: CONSENTHQ indicates whether or not the respondent for the household survey consented to be interviewed and completed the survey. The variable RESULTHQ provides more detail regarding why the interview was not conducted or completed.

var.name: AVAILABLEHQ_1
var.labl: Household respondent present and available at least once
var.txt: AVAILABLEHQ indicates whether a member of the household was available to be interviewed. This is recorded by the interviewer prior to beginning the household questionnaire.

var.name: AVAILABLEHQ_2
var.labl: Household respondent present and available at least once
var.txt: AVAILABLEHQ indicates whether a member of the household was available to be interviewed. This is recorded by the interviewer prior to beginning the household questionnaire.

var.name: VISITNUMHQ_1
var.txt:
VISITNUMHQ reports the number of times the enumerator visited the household to reach the household respondent. Enumerators would visit up to three times.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

var.name: VISITNUMHQ_2
var.txt:
VISITNUMHQ reports the number of times the enumerator visited the household to reach the household respondent. Enumerators would visit up to three times.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

var.name: RESULTHQ_1
var.txt: RESULTHQ indicates whether the household questionnaire was completed and, if not, why not. For example, the household survey could not be completed if the household members refused to participate in the survey, if they were not at home during repeated visits, or if the dwelling was destroyed and uninhabited.

var.name: RESULTHQ_2
var.txt: RESULTHQ indicates whether the household questionnaire was completed and, if not, why not. For example, the household survey could not be completed if the household members refused to participate in the survey, if they were not at home during repeated visits, or if the dwelling was destroyed and uninhabited.

var.name: RESULTLHQ_1
var.txt: RESULTLHQ indicates whether the household questionnaire for the longitudinal survey design was completed and, if not, why not. For example, the household survey could not be completed if the household members refused to participate in the survey, if the household moved between survey follow-ups, if they were not at home during repeated visits, or if the dwelling was destroyed and uninhabited.

var.name: RESULTLHQ_2
var.txt: RESULTLHQ indicates whether the household questionnaire for the longitudinal survey design was completed and, if not, why not. For example, the household survey could not be completed if the household members refused to participate in the survey, if the household moved between survey follow-ups, if they were not at home during repeated visits, or if the dwelling was destroyed and uninhabited.

var.name: INTHQMON_1
var.txt: INTHQMON reports the calendar month in which the interview for the household questionnaire was conducted. The year of the household interview can be found in the variable INTHQYEAR.

var.name: INTHQMON_2
var.txt: INTHQMON reports the calendar month in which the interview for the household questionnaire was conducted. The year of the household interview can be found in the variable INTHQYEAR.

var.name: INTHQYEAR_1
var.txt: INTHQYEAR reports the calendar year in which the interview for the household questionnaire was conducted. The month of the household interview can be found in the variable INTHQMON.

var.name: INTHQYEAR_2
var.txt: INTHQYEAR reports the calendar year in which the interview for the household questionnaire was conducted. The month of the household interview can be found in the variable INTHQMON.

var.name: HHIDORIG_1
var.txt:
HHIDORIG reports the household identification code from the original data assigned by PMA. Each code was a randomly generated series of numbers and letters.
IPUMS has generated its own household identification number HHID.
HHIDORIG does not allow users to link records of households that have been interviewed in more than one survey round of PMA.
var.codInstr: HHIDORIG is a 50-character string variable.

var.name: HHIDORIG_2
var.txt:
HHIDORIG reports the household identification code from the original data assigned by PMA. Each code was a randomly generated series of numbers and letters.
IPUMS has generated its own household identification number HHID.
HHIDORIG does not allow users to link records of households that have been interviewed in more than one survey round of PMA.
var.codInstr: HHIDORIG is a 50-character string variable.

var.name: ABORFOLLOWUP_1
var.labl: Willing to be followed-up to discuss regarding pregnancy ending experience
var.txt:
For women who have ever regulated their period because of a suspected pregnancy or who have ever ended a pregnancy, ABORFOLLOWUP indicates whether they consented to a follow-up interview to discuss decision-making processes related to either ending their pregnancy or bringing back their period, as appropriate.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: ABORFOLLOWUP_2
var.labl: Willing to be followed-up to discuss regarding pregnancy ending experience
var.txt:
For women who have ever regulated their period because of a suspected pregnancy or who have ever ended a pregnancy, ABORFOLLOWUP indicates whether they consented to a follow-up interview to discuss decision-making processes related to either ending their pregnancy or bringing back their period, as appropriate.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PERSONIDORIG_1
var.txt: PERSONIDORIG is the original person identification code assigned by PMA2020. Each code was a randomly generated series of numbers and letters with the person's line number within the household concatenated onto the end.
var.codInstr: PERSONIDORIG is a 55-character string variable.

var.name: PERSONIDORIG_2
var.txt: PERSONIDORIG is the original person identification code assigned by PMA2020. Each code was a randomly generated series of numbers and letters with the person's line number within the household concatenated onto the end.
var.codInstr: PERSONIDORIG is a 55-character string variable.

var.name: LINEORIG_1
var.txt: LINEORIG is a technical variable that numbers all persons within each household. The related variable LINENO is an IPUMS-generated line number of a household member according to their order in the original data. The main difference between LINEORIG and LINENO is that values in LINENO are without duplicates and have been corrected when numbers in LINEORIG were skipped.
var.codInstr: LINEORIG is a 2-digit numeric variable that represents the household member's line number within the household in the original data.

var.name: LINEORIG_2
var.txt: LINEORIG is a technical variable that numbers all persons within each household. The related variable LINENO is an IPUMS-generated line number of a household member according to their order in the original data. The main difference between LINEORIG and LINENO is that values in LINENO are without duplicates and have been corrected when numbers in LINEORIG were skipped.
var.codInstr: LINEORIG is a 2-digit numeric variable that represents the household member's line number within the household in the original data.

var.name: SURVEYWILLING_1
var.labl: Willing to participate in another survey
var.txt:
SURVEYWILLING indicates whether the woman would be willing to participate in another survey on this or any other topic either by phone or in person at some point in the future.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: SURVEYWILLING_2
var.labl: Willing to participate in another survey
var.txt:
SURVEYWILLING indicates whether the woman would be willing to participate in another survey on this or any other topic either by phone or in person at some point in the future.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: COUNTRYSTR_1
var.txt: COUNTRYSTR reports the country where the survey was fielded. The codes assigned to each country are the alpha-2 codes (a two-character string) used by the UN Statistics Division and the ISO (International Organization for Standardization).
var.codInstr:
This variable is a 2-letter variable that takes the following values:
BF = Burkina Faso CD = Congo, Democratic Republic CI = Cote d'Ivoire ET = Ethiopia GH = Ghana ID = Indonesia IN = India KE = Kenya NE = Niger NG = Nigeria UG = Uganda

var.name: COUNTRYSTR_2
var.txt: COUNTRYSTR reports the country where the survey was fielded. The codes assigned to each country are the alpha-2 codes (a two-character string) used by the UN Statistics Division and the ISO (International Organization for Standardization).
var.codInstr:
This variable is a 2-letter variable that takes the following values:
BF = Burkina Faso CD = Congo, Democratic Republic CI = Cote d'Ivoire ET = Ethiopia GH = Ghana ID = Indonesia IN = India KE = Kenya NE = Niger NG = Nigeria UG = Uganda

var.name: FQWEIGHT_1
var.txt:
FQWEIGHT is a nationally representative inverse probability weight for respondents of the female questionnaire. FQWEIGHT should be used in analyses of all questions on the female questionnaire. FQWEIGHT controls for female non-response, but because all eligible females in the household responded to the questionnaire, respondent selection probability does not need to be controlled for. For more details on how FQWEIGHT was calculated, please see the Weighting Memo from the PMA team.
For person records who were not women aged 15 to 49, the value of FQWEIGHT is zero.
var.codInstr: This variable is a 17-digit variable with decimal points. All cases that are missing or NIU (not in universe) are coded as zero.

var.name: FQWEIGHT_2
var.txt:
FQWEIGHT is a nationally representative inverse probability weight for respondents of the female questionnaire. FQWEIGHT should be used in analyses of all questions on the female questionnaire. FQWEIGHT controls for female non-response, but because all eligible females in the household responded to the questionnaire, respondent selection probability does not need to be controlled for. For more details on how FQWEIGHT was calculated, please see the Weighting Memo from the PMA team.
For person records who were not women aged 15 to 49, the value of FQWEIGHT is zero.
var.codInstr: This variable is a 17-digit variable with decimal points. All cases that are missing or NIU (not in universe) are coded as zero.

var.name: PANELWEIGHT
var.txt:
PANELWEIGHT is an inverse probability weight for respondents of the longitudinal panel on family planning. PANELWEIGHT should be used in analyses of all questions on the female questionnaire for women who were interviewed in both Phase 1 and Phase 2 survey rounds.
For person records who were not women aged 15 to 49, or women who were not interviewed in both Phase 1 and Phase 2, the value of PANELWEIGHT is zero or missing.
var.codInstr: This variable is a 17-digit variable with decimal points. All cases that are missing or NIU (not in universe) are coded as zero.

var.name: HQWEIGHT_1
var.txt:
HQWEIGHT is an inverse probability weight, or the selection probability of selecting the household in the enumeration area (EAID). HQWEIGHT can be used as a nationally representative inverse probability weight for households, and should be used in analyses of all questions on the household questionnaire. HQWEIGHT controls for household and female non-response, but because there are multiple people in one household, analyses should be restricted to one person per household, using LINENO. Most simply, analyses can be restricted to persons with LINENO equal to 1. This restriction yields one result per household and thus appropriately gives equal weight to households with one member and households with many members.
For more details on how HQWEIGHT was calculated, please see the Weighting Memo from the PMA team.
var.codInstr: This variable is a 17-digit variable with decimal points. All cases that are missing or NIU (not in universe) are coded as zero.

var.name: HQWEIGHT_2
var.txt:
HQWEIGHT is an inverse probability weight, or the selection probability of selecting the household in the enumeration area (EAID). HQWEIGHT can be used as a nationally representative inverse probability weight for households, and should be used in analyses of all questions on the household questionnaire. HQWEIGHT controls for household and female non-response, but because there are multiple people in one household, analyses should be restricted to one person per household, using LINENO. Most simply, analyses can be restricted to persons with LINENO equal to 1. This restriction yields one result per household and thus appropriately gives equal weight to households with one member and households with many members.
For more details on how HQWEIGHT was calculated, please see the Weighting Memo from the PMA team.
var.codInstr: This variable is a 17-digit variable with decimal points. All cases that are missing or NIU (not in universe) are coded as zero.

var.name: STRATA_1
var.txt:
STRATA defines the stratification for each sample. Some countries use only urban/rural stratification, others use regions, and some use both levels of stratification. Users may use STRATA and EAID (the primary sampling unit) to adjust sampling errors to account for sampling design of IPUMS-PMA samples.
For more information on sample design for IPUMS-PMA surveys, see the sampling design memo for households and women.

var.name: STRATA_2
var.txt:
STRATA defines the stratification for each sample. Some countries use only urban/rural stratification, others use regions, and some use both levels of stratification. Users may use STRATA and EAID (the primary sampling unit) to adjust sampling errors to account for sampling design of IPUMS-PMA samples.
For more information on sample design for IPUMS-PMA surveys, see the sampling design memo for households and women.

var.name: AGEHQ_1
var.txt:
AGEHQ reports the household member's age in years as reported by the respondent to the household questionnaire, not necessarily the person him/herself. Individuals less than one year old are coded as '0'.
Note that for some cases, AGEHQ might differ from the age reported by women in the household who were eligible for the female questionnaire (AGE). Because AGE is reported directly by the individual, it is likely to be more accurate in cases of conflict between AGEHQ and AGE.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire. For maternal and newborn health samples, the question was included in the household screening questionnaire and reflects only responses for the infant's mother.

var.name: AGEHQ_2
var.txt:
AGEHQ reports the household member's age in years as reported by the respondent to the household questionnaire, not necessarily the person him/herself. Individuals less than one year old are coded as '0'.
Note that for some cases, AGEHQ might differ from the age reported by women in the household who were eligible for the female questionnaire (AGE). Because AGE is reported directly by the individual, it is likely to be more accurate in cases of conflict between AGEHQ and AGE.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire. For maternal and newborn health samples, the question was included in the household screening questionnaire and reflects only responses for the infant's mother.

var.name: SEX_1
var.txt: SEX indicates whether the individual listed in the household roster was male or female. Note that SEX differs from the variable SEXHQ, which reports the sex of the respondent to the household questionnaire.

var.name: SEX_2
var.txt: SEX indicates whether the individual listed in the household roster was male or female. Note that SEX differs from the variable SEXHQ, which reports the sex of the respondent to the household questionnaire.

var.name: MARSTATHQ_1
var.txt: MARSTATHQ reports the marital status of individuals in the household, as stated by the household respondent. Users may note that for some cases, MARSTATHQ might differ from the marital status reported by women in the household who were eligible for the female questionnaire (MARSTAT). Because MARSTAT is reported directly by the individual, it is likely to be more accurate in cases of conflict between MARSTATHQ and MARSTAT.

var.name: MARSTATHQ_2
var.txt: MARSTATHQ reports the marital status of individuals in the household, as stated by the household respondent. Users may note that for some cases, MARSTATHQ might differ from the marital status reported by women in the household who were eligible for the female questionnaire (MARSTAT). Because MARSTAT is reported directly by the individual, it is likely to be more accurate in cases of conflict between MARSTATHQ and MARSTAT.

var.name: RELATE_1
var.txt:
RELATE indicates the relationship of the person to the head of the household, as reported by the household questionnaire respondent.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire. For maternal and newborn health samples, the question was included in the household screening questionnaire and reflects only responses for the infant's mother.

var.name: RELATE_2
var.txt:
RELATE indicates the relationship of the person to the head of the household, as reported by the household questionnaire respondent.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire. For maternal and newborn health samples, the question was included in the household screening questionnaire and reflects only responses for the infant's mother.

var.name: RESIDENT_1
var.txt:
RESIDENT indicates whether the person was a usual member of the household or a visitor. Usual members of the household who did not sleep in the household the previous night were included in the household roster.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire. For maternal and newborn health samples, the question was included in the household screening questionnaire and reflects only responses for the infant's mother.

catgry.labl: No, does not usually live in household
Visitor, slept in hh last night
Usual member, did not sleep in hh last night
Usual member, slept in hh last night
Slept in hh last night, no response if usually lives in hh

var.name: RESIDENT_2
var.txt:
RESIDENT indicates whether the person was a usual member of the household or a visitor. Usual members of the household who did not sleep in the household the previous night were included in the household roster.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire. For maternal and newborn health samples, the question was included in the household screening questionnaire and reflects only responses for the infant's mother.

catgry.labl: No, does not usually live in household
Visitor, slept in hh last night
Usual member, did not sleep in hh last night
Usual member, slept in hh last night
Slept in hh last night, no response if usually lives in hh

var.name: RESULTPANEL_1
var.txt: RESULTPANEL indicates whether or not the respondent who was interviewed in Phase 1 completed the female questionnaire in a later Phase, and, if not, the reason why not.

var.name: RESULTPANEL_2
var.txt: RESULTPANEL indicates whether or not the respondent who was interviewed in Phase 1 completed the female questionnaire in a later Phase, and, if not, the reason why not.

var.name: PANELWOMAN_1
var.txt:
PANELWOMAN indicates whether the record represents a woman who was interviewed in Phase 1 (baseline survey) of the longitudinal family planning survey.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PANELWOMAN_2
var.txt:
PANELWOMAN indicates whether the record represents a woman who was interviewed in Phase 1 (baseline survey) of the longitudinal family planning survey.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: HHPANELP1_1
var.labl: Panel woman lived in this dwelling in Phase 1
var.txt: For persons enumerated in Phase 2, HHPANELP1 indicates that a woman in the longitudinal family planning panel lived in the person's current physical dwelling at Phase 1 (the baseline survey).

var.name: HHPANELP1_2
var.labl: Panel woman lived in this dwelling in Phase 1
var.txt: For persons enumerated in Phase 2, HHPANELP1 indicates that a woman in the longitudinal family planning panel lived in the person's current physical dwelling at Phase 1 (the baseline survey).

var.name: NEWPANELFEM_1
var.labl: Woman enrolled in panel in Phase 2
var.txt:
For women who were not interviewed in the Phase 1 (baseline) survey, NEWPANELFEM indicates whether they were enrolled during Phase 2.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: NEWPANELFEM_2
var.labl: Woman enrolled in panel in Phase 2
var.txt:
For women who were not interviewed in the Phase 1 (baseline) survey, NEWPANELFEM indicates whether they were enrolled during Phase 2.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: HHPANELP2_1
var.labl: Panel woman from Phase 1 lives in this dwelling in Phase 2
var.txt: HHPANELP2 indicates whether a woman interviewed in Phase 1 was living in the dwelling in Phase 2.

var.name: HHPANELP2_2
var.labl: Panel woman from Phase 1 lives in this dwelling in Phase 2
var.txt: HHPANELP2 indicates whether a woman interviewed in Phase 1 was living in the dwelling in Phase 2.

var.name: HHTYPE_1
var.txt:
HHTYPE reports the household's follow up type in Phase 2. The household could be the same as the Phase 1 household if at least one original resident was still living there. The household could be a replacement household sampled in areas of high household attrition. The household could also be the new household of a panel woman who moved within the study area between Phase 1 and Phase 2.
See the sample notes documentation for more information on the longitudinal data.

var.name: HHTYPE_2
var.txt:
HHTYPE reports the household's follow up type in Phase 2. The household could be the same as the Phase 1 household if at least one original resident was still living there. The household could be a replacement household sampled in areas of high household attrition. The household could also be the new household of a panel woman who moved within the study area between Phase 1 and Phase 2.
See the sample notes documentation for more information on the longitudinal data.

var.name: HHSTATUS_1
var.txt: HHSTATUS reports the status of the Phase 1 household if they are no longer living in their previous dwelling at the time of the Phase 2 interview one year later.

var.name: HHSTATUS_2
var.txt: HHSTATUS reports the status of the Phase 1 household if they are no longer living in their previous dwelling at the time of the Phase 2 interview one year later.

var.name: HHREPLACED_1
var.txt: HHREPLACED indicates whether the person was a member of a household that was newly sampled for the Phase 2 longitudinal family planning survey due to more than 10 percent attrition within one EA since the Phase 1 survey round.

var.name: HHREPLACED_2
var.txt: HHREPLACED indicates whether the person was a member of a household that was newly sampled for the Phase 2 longitudinal family planning survey due to more than 10 percent attrition within one EA since the Phase 1 survey round.

var.name: SAMEDWELLING_1
var.labl: Living in same dwelling unit as Phase 1
var.txt: SAMEDWELLING indicates whether the person was living in the same dwelling in Phase 2 as they were in Phase 1 of the longitudinal family planning survey.

var.name: SAMEDWELLING_2
var.labl: Living in same dwelling unit as Phase 1
var.txt: SAMEDWELLING indicates whether the person was living in the same dwelling in Phase 2 as they were in Phase 1 of the longitudinal family planning survey.

var.name: HHOCCUPIED_1
var.txt:
For households that are residing in the same dwelling unit as they were during Phase 1 of the survey, HHOCCUPIED indicates whether any people are currently living in this dwelling unit.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

var.name: HHOCCUPIED_2
var.txt:
For households that are residing in the same dwelling unit as they were during Phase 1 of the survey, HHOCCUPIED indicates whether any people are currently living in this dwelling unit.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

var.name: HHMEMSTAT_1
var.labl: Status of household member from baseline survey
var.txt:
For household members who had been enumerated in a longitudinal household survey, HHMEMSTAT reports whether the household member was still a resident of the household in the follow-up survey, and if not, the reason why. The person could have been still a resident, moved away, died, or the interviewer might have been unable to find knowledgeable household members or neighbors to determine that person's status.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

catgry.labl: Moved out of household for school

var.name: HHMEMSTAT_2
var.labl: Status of household member from baseline survey
var.txt:
For household members who had been enumerated in a longitudinal household survey, HHMEMSTAT reports whether the household member was still a resident of the household in the follow-up survey, and if not, the reason why. The person could have been still a resident, moved away, died, or the interviewer might have been unable to find knowledgeable household members or neighbors to determine that person's status.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

catgry.labl: Moved out of household for school

var.name: HHMEMUPDATE_1
var.labl: Demographic data of household member updated
var.txt: For household members who were residents in both Phase 1 and Phase 2, HHMEMUPDATE indicates whether the household member's demographic information was updated between Phase 1 and Phase 2.

var.name: HHMEMUPDATE_2
var.labl: Demographic data of household member updated
var.txt: For household members who were residents in both Phase 1 and Phase 2, HHMEMUPDATE indicates whether the household member's demographic information was updated between Phase 1 and Phase 2.

var.name: HHNEWYR_1
var.labl: Household structure was built in past 12 months
var.txt: HHNEWYR indicates whether the dwelling the Phase 2 household was living in was constructed in the past 12 months.

var.name: HHNEWYR_2
var.labl: Household structure was built in past 12 months
var.txt: HHNEWYR indicates whether the dwelling the Phase 2 household was living in was constructed in the past 12 months.

var.name: HHVACANTWHY_1
var.labl: Reason for no people living in sampled dwelling
var.txt:
For dwelling units that were included in the Phase 1 (baseline) survey and do not currently have people living in them, HHVACANTWHY indicates why people are not currently living in the dwelling unit.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

catgry.labl: Phase 1 dwelling unit vacant or address not a dwelling unit
Phase 1 dwelling unit was not found

var.name: HHVACANTWHY_2
var.labl: Reason for no people living in sampled dwelling
var.txt:
For dwelling units that were included in the Phase 1 (baseline) survey and do not currently have people living in them, HHVACANTWHY indicates why people are not currently living in the dwelling unit.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

catgry.labl: Phase 1 dwelling unit vacant or address not a dwelling unit
Phase 1 dwelling unit was not found

var.name: HHIDORIGP1DWELL_1
var.txt: HHIDORIGP1DWELL is the original PMA dwelling identifier from the Phase 1 longitudinal family planning survey contained in the Phase 2. This variable identifies the physical space, not necessarily the household members. HHIDORIGP1DWELL is the same as HHIDORIGP1 if the individual lived in the same dwelling in both Phase 1 and Phase 2.
var.codInstr: This is a 50-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: HHIDORIGP1DWELL_2
var.txt: HHIDORIGP1DWELL is the original PMA dwelling identifier from the Phase 1 longitudinal family planning survey contained in the Phase 2. This variable identifies the physical space, not necessarily the household members. HHIDORIGP1DWELL is the same as HHIDORIGP1 if the individual lived in the same dwelling in both Phase 1 and Phase 2.
var.codInstr: This is a 50-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: HHMEMPRESP1_1
var.labl: At least one original household member present
var.txt: HHMEMPRESP1 indicates whether at least one Phase 1 household member was still present in Phase 2.

var.name: HHMEMPRESP1_2
var.labl: At least one original household member present
var.txt: HHMEMPRESP1 indicates whether at least one Phase 1 household member was still present in Phase 2.

var.name: HHIDORIGP1
var.txt: HHIDORIGP1 is the original PMA household identifier from the Phase 1 longitudinal family planning survey contained in the Phase 2 data for persons who also appeared in the Phase 1 household roster. HHIDORIGP1 is the same as HHIDORIGP1DWELL if the individual lived in the same dwelling in both Phase 1 and Phase 2. If the person has moved to a different dwelling, HHIDORIGP1 in Phase 2 is the same as HHIDORIG in the Phase 1 data, allowing users to match the person to their household in Phase 1.
var.codInstr: This is a 50-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: PHONEOWN1_1
var.txt:
For women who have consented to either the panel survey or abortion survey follow up, PHONEOWN1 indicates whether the primary phone number that she has provided is her personal phone number, one that is not shared with other people.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PHONEOWN1_2
var.txt:
For women who have consented to either the panel survey or abortion survey follow up, PHONEOWN1 indicates whether the primary phone number that she has provided is her personal phone number, one that is not shared with other people.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PHONEWILLINGHQ_1
var.labl: Willing to give phone number for follow-up
var.txt:
PHONEWILLINGHQ indicates whether the household respondent was willing to provide their personal phone number for follow-up.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

var.name: PHONEWILLINGHQ_2
var.labl: Willing to give phone number for follow-up
var.txt:
PHONEWILLINGHQ indicates whether the household respondent was willing to provide their personal phone number for follow-up.
The question associated with this variable was included in the household questionnaire.

var.name: PHONEOWN2_1
var.txt:
For women who have consented to either the panel survey or abortion survey follow up, PHONEOWN2 indicates whether the secondary phone number that she has provided is her personal phone number, one that is not shared with other people.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PHONEOWN2_2
var.txt:
For women who have consented to either the panel survey or abortion survey follow up, PHONEOWN2 indicates whether the secondary phone number that she has provided is her personal phone number, one that is not shared with other people.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PHONEWILLING2_1
var.labl: Willing to give secondary number for follow-up
var.txt:
For women who have consented to either the panel survey or abortion survey follow up, PHONEWILLING2 indicates whether she is willing to provide her secondary phone number for this purpose.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.

var.name: PHONEWILLING2_2
var.labl: Willing to give secondary number for follow-up
var.txt:
For women who have consented to either the panel survey or abortion survey follow up, PHONEWILLING2 indicates whether she is willing to provide her secondary phone number for this purpose.
The question associated with this variable was included in the female questionnaire.
